segment_selection_rules: Select segments that open with a concrete, counterintuitive numeric comparison (e.g., 'Vitamin C in 1 lettuce leaf ≈ 1 sheet of A4 paper')—start clip on the first shocking claim, not on setup questions.
Select segments that immediately answer 'why/ how' with a vivid mechanism explanation (e.g., 'never saw soil' → 'grown on cotton in sugar bath' → 'stacked greenhouses'). Keep the causal chain intact.

Select segments that contain sensory/visualizable nouns and locations (Holland/Spain, Supermarkt, Boden/Erdreich, Wattebausch, Zuckerbad, Gewächshaus, Etagen) because they generate imagery without needing visuals.
Select segments that contain implicit consumer relevance ('in the supermarket', '19 or 29 cents') to anchor the claim in the viewer’s daily life.

Remove segments that are primarily conversational scaffolding (questions like 'Was schätzt du?', audience interaction, hedges) unless they add conflict; here the clip drops the estimate-question and jumps to the punchline.

Remove segments that broaden scope into policy/authority references (e.g., DGE guidelines, international comparisons, definitions like 'Molekularmediziner') when the viral angle is a single concrete product myth-bust.

Prefer a 1-topic micro-story over multi-topic nutrition context: keep only the 'iceberg lettuce nutrient emptiness + industrial growing method' storyline; cut adjacent vitamin C-in-apple and RDA debate.
End on a strong evaluative button line ('Das ist brutal.') or equivalent moral verdict; if none exists, select the nearest high-emotion judgment sentence as the final segment.

timing_patterns.clip_length_optimal: 35-50 seconds (example: 41s) for a single shocking claim + mechanism explanation + judgment
timing_patterns.hook_position: 0-3 seconds (start directly on the strongest comparison/claim; no preamble)
timing_patterns.payoff_position: last 3-8 seconds (price anchor + broader implication + emotional verdict)
pacing_rules: Use a 'claim → implication → mechanism' cadence with no detours: (1) shocking comparison, (2) consumer action implication ('you don’t even need to wash it'), (3) explanation of industrial process.
Keep sentence density high: avoid pauses, definitions, and external references; the selected 3 segments are consecutive and maintain momentum.

Maintain escalating specificity every ~8-12 seconds: comparison (paper) → hygiene implication (no washing) → soil absence → cotton/sugar bath → multi-level greenhouses → nutrient solution → cheap price.
Cut at topic boundaries, not mid-argument: include only contiguous segments until the argument resolves; stop immediately after the strongest concluding judgment.

kept_characteristics: Shock statistic/comparison that is easy to repeat verbatim (A4 paper analogy).
Everyday object framing (iceberg lettuce from supermarket) with geographic specificity (Holland/Spain).
Myth reversal / expectation violation (you 'don’t need to wash' because it never touched soil).
Concrete industrial process description that creates vivid mental images (cotton ball in sugar bath, stacked greenhouses, nutrient solution).
Implicit outrage trigger via low price point ('19/29 cents') and a moral tag ('brutal').
removed_characteristics: Interactive Q&A setup and softening language (asking the listener to guess, conversational fillers).
Broader nutritional context and additional examples (apple vitamin C decline) that dilute the single narrative.
Appeals to authority and guideline debates (DGE recommendations, cross-country comparisons).
Long explanatory tangents/definitions (what molecular medicine is, individualized dosage discussion).
transition_points: Cut IN at longform ~32.4s: begins exactly at the first fully-formed shocking claim (no lead-in about buying lettuce or guessing vitamin C).
Hard cut between kept segments is minimal because segments [5,6,7] are contiguous; the restructure relies on a continuous monologue without re-contextualization.
Cut OUT at longform ~79.9s: ends right after the price anchor and emotional verdict, before the narrative shifts to apple vitamin C and dietary guidelines.

what_makes_good_cut: Standalone comprehension: viewer understands the claim and why it matters without needing earlier context (starts on the comparison).
Single-thread escalation: each subsequent sentence increases specificity and stakes (paper → no soil → sugar bath → cheap price).
High quotability: contains at least one repeatable line/metaphor and one punchy judgment closer.
Concrete anchors: includes place/product/price details that feel verifiable and personal.
No topic switching: ends before the speaker pivots to a new example or abstract guideline discussion.
what_makes_bad_cut: Starts with setup questions or vague context that delays the first shock beyond ~3 seconds.
Includes multiple nutrition topics (e.g., apples + RDAs + medical definitions) causing narrative diffusion.
Cuts before the mechanism explanation, leaving only a claim that feels like unsupported rage-bait.
Ends without a closing verdict or implication, producing a 'hanging' feeling and lower shareability.
Uses authority-name drops or numbers without imagery, reducing emotional/visual retention.
